name: Mars
name_theory: Mars is named after the Roman god of war due to its reddish appearance, which resembles blood. The planet's distinct red color is due to iron oxide, commonly known as rust, on its surface.
description: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun and is often referred to as the 'Red Planet' because of its reddish appearance. It has the tallest volcano and the deepest, longest canyon in the Solar System.

gallery.description: Olympus Mons, the tallest volcano in the Solar System

interesting_facts: Mars is home to the tallest volcano in the Solar System, Olympus Mons, which is about 13.6 miles (22 kilometers) high.
The planet has the largest canyon in the Solar System, Valles Marineris, which stretches over 2,500 miles (4,000 kilometers) long and reaches depths of up to 7 miles (11 kilometers).
Mars has two small moons, Phobos and Deimos, which are thought to be captured asteroids.
A Martian day, or sol, is only slightly longer than an Earth day, lasting 24.6 hours.
Mars experiences seasons similar to Earth due to its axial tilt, though they last about twice as long because of its longer orbit around the Sun.
The atmosphere of Mars is very thin, composed mostly of carbon dioxide (95.3%), nitrogen (2.7%), and argon (1.6%).
Mars has the largest dust storms in the Solar System, sometimes covering the entire planet and lasting for months.
The surface of Mars has signs of ancient river valleys, lakes, and flood plains, indicating that liquid water once existed on the planet.
Mars has been visited by numerous spacecraft from Earth, including orbiters, landers, and rovers, such as Viking, Pathfinder, Spirit, Opportunity, Curiosity, and Perseverance.
Mars's gravity is only about 38% that of Earth's, which means you could jump nearly three times higher on Mars than you can on Earth.
The thin atmosphere on Mars means that liquid water cannot exist on its surface for long without evaporating or freezing.
Mars's reddish color is due to iron oxide, or rust, on its surface.
The first successful flyby of Mars was by NASA's Mariner 4 in 1965, which sent back the first close-up images of the Martian surface.
The Curiosity rover discovered evidence of ancient conditions that could have supported microbial life on Mars.
Mars has been a target for potential human exploration due to its relatively hospitable environment compared to other planets.
